reviewDescription: Good piece of kit overall.  Timer function is quite handy, the brush 'stutters' every 30 sec so you can change the areas you are brushing.  After 2 min it does a long stutter, indicating that you are done.  Quite handy.  Charge is good, lasts about a week+ using once/ day.  Brush action is strong and vigorous. Made by Braun, my past experience is these last a long time. Overall good bang for buck electric brush. Dentist reports plaque build-up is much reduced compared to manual brush. Have not tested any other features.

I invested in the Oral-B Pro 1000 Rechargeable Electric Toothbrush, and after incorporating it into my daily oral care routine, I can confidently say it's a game-changer. This electric toothbrush combines cutting-edge technology with user-friendly features, delivering an exceptional dental care experience.First and foremost, the cleaning performance of the Oral-B Pro 1000 is outstanding. The oscillating, rotating, and pulsating movements of the brush head ensure a thorough and efficient clean, reaching areas that manual brushing might miss. The 3D cleaning action leaves my teeth feeling remarkably clean and polished after each use.The pressure sensor feature is a standout addition. It alerts me when I'm applying too much pressure while brushing, preventing potential damage to my gums and enamel. This feature is especially beneficial for those who may not be aware of their brushing habits, promoting a gentle yet effective oral care routine.The built-in timer is another noteworthy feature that encourages optimal brushing habits. The two-minute timer ensures that I brush for the dentist-recommended duration, and the 30-second intervals prompt me to switch to different quadrants of my mouth, ensuring a thorough and even clean.The simplicity of the Oral-B Pro 1000 is one of its strengths. The on/off button is easy to use, and the single cleaning mode streamlines the brushing process. The brush head is also easily replaceable, and it's compatible with a variety of Oral-B brush heads, allowing for a personalized cleaning experience.The battery life of the Oral-B Pro 1000 is impressive. A single full charge lasts for several days, making it convenient for travel or forgetful moments when I've neglected to charge it. The charging indicator is a helpful feature, ensuring that I'm always aware of the battery status.Maintaining the Oral-B Pro 1000 is a breeze. The waterproof design allows for easy cleaning under the tap, and the brush head storage compartment is a thoughtful addition, keeping the brush head protected and hygienic between uses.In conclusion, the Oral-B Pro 1000 Rechargeable Electric Toothbrush has become an integral part of my daily oral care routine. Its powerful cleaning performance, user-friendly features, and thoughtful design make it a standout choice in the world of electric toothbrushes. If you're looking to elevate your oral care game, the Oral-B Pro 1000 is a wise and effective investment.

Pros*Powerful*Good grip*Lightweight*Easy and convenient charging base*Long and thin handle is surprisingly good for reaching the back of my tongue without making me gag too much.Cons*Cleaning modes seem gimmicky but do work well as power settings if you don't like the more powerful setting.*The brush head doesn't make full contact with the base. There's a tiny gap that wasn't there in my older Pro 100. This doesn't seem to affect the functionality at all, nor does it feel loose. It's more of an aesthetic issue.*The pressure indicator should be more noticeable, maybe there should be an LED indicator. Right now, it's supposed to be a pulsation, but it almost sounds like a change of pitch. Sometimes it's hard to tell if it's making that sound.This is replacing my 4 year old Oral B Pro 100 electric toothbrush that uses AA batteries. What I was able to notice right away was how easy it was to charge. It's almost like a magnetic charger, without any exposed metal bits that could corrode. The 3 power modes are useful, but I mainly use the most powerful setting or daily clean mode, although in that setting is harder to notice the pressure indicator, which is basically like a pulsating noise and sensation that changes when you put too much pressure on it. The second power setting makes it more noticeable, that's supposed to be the sensitive mode. The third power setting or the whitening mode has a stronger pulsating or hammering sensation, this mode slows down, then ramps up again, but in average it seems a little slower than the Pro 100 at full charge. I don't know if it actually whitens the teeth though, I think it's just a gimmick. For $40 I can fully recommend this.

I had a different type of electric toothbrush and only used it a couple of times.  I did not like it as it was one with the built in water pik.  When I purchased this, I was half expecting to send it back.  I was pleasantly surprised by how well this one works and cleans my teeth.  The head that comes with this toothbrush was too hard, so I purchased replacement heads for sensitive teeth.  I still soak them in hot water before using, but they are much softer and easier on my teeth.  If you are planning on purchasing this, I recommend the softer bristle heads.

I've used both the Sonicare and the Oral B and while either is a huge step up from manual toothbrushes, I get better check-ups with the Oral B.  My cleanings now usually only take about 30 minutes in and out.  There's very little tartar that needs to be removed and my gums are in good shape.  I must add, however, that I also use the waterpik flosser which I think greatly helps.  I've seen some negative comments about having to tap the power button a few times to get it to turn off, but that shouldn't be a surprise since the description mentions the 3 brushing modes.  I do wish it would automatically shut off after the 2 minutes like the Sonicare does.  I also like the variety of brush heads that are available for the Oral B brushes.  Overall I would highly recommend this toothbrush.  I know both the Sonicare and Oral B offer several models of toothbrushes, but this basic model does a fine job and I see no need to upgrade.

reviewTitle: I like this better than sonicare so far! Going from sonicare to this basic oral b model.
reviewDescription: I was skeptical to switch from sonicare to oral b given how basic this seemed to be, but I have no regrets so far. Sonicare is good in terms of cleaning in between gums but I always could not get my teeth white. After trying oral b, it is way different as it gets in the corners of your teeth and it does a polish kind of brushing so my teeth seem to be whiter.  For this basic model its actually pretty great as its basic in terms of one button to push (although it has 3 modes you can switch between) the first mode seems strong enough yet gentle for my teeth and gums.  As for noise, many were saying it was loud, but honestly it was not. My sonicare made a more annoying whining noise than this, so I'm happy and can't complain about the noise. Battery life seems basic but just put it in the charger every few days or so. Only thing I didn't like is that I can never tell when to stop brushing, as my sonicare would turn itself off, but this one gives gentle haptic feedback, but doesn't really turn off after the full 2 minutes.  So I really can't tell if it wants me to switch brushing areas or stop brushing.  But overall this was a great switch so far and I'll be sticking with oral b so far.

I have one of these for myself, so I bought my boyfriend a matching one as a present! He loves it!PROS:- easy to clean your teeth with, definitely gives you a good thorough clean feel- easy to clean the actual toothbrush itself as well- love that it comes with a charging stand to set up in the bathroom- also love that you can purchase replacement brushes for it once yours gets too worn down- great for travel -- doesn't lose charge for a LONG time, mine has gone days without being charged and I never had battery issuesCONS:- it is frustrating to have to fight with the charging cord sometimes -- it's a little thick/stiff so sometimes you really have to maneuver it to ensure that your toothbrush stands up in place

reviewTitle: All the features I ever need from an electric toothbrush
reviewDescription: This is my 2nd Pro1000 after 6+ years of daily use.  It actually still works well I am only replacing it because  its rubberized handle is partially pealed off from the body, I fear water will get into the unit soon enough.  The handle has also picked up a musty odor recently that I can't get rid of.  I am glad to see that the new model has a different - non-porous - material for the handle.  For those complaining of needing to press the power button a few times to turn it off, here's an excerpt from Braun's FAQ regarding that:  "... repeated presses of the on/off button when the toothbrush is first switched on will cycle through the brushing modes, and holding the on/off button down will turn it off."

I've never used a battery toothbrush before and decided to give one a whirl. My partners idea because they wanted one.  They love it , me not so much. Hey the product is awesome but I jave sensitive teeth and this little machine has some power to it. Makes my eyeballs shake and well my teeth are too sensitive to use this every day. So I only use it once a week , the rest of the time I'm back to my trusty toothbrush. Great product and price though.

reviewTitle: Hygienist said I can clean her teeth next time
reviewDescription: I got this toothbrush two years ago, and I’m coming back to leave a review because my hygienist has told me on my last four visits (since getting this toothbrush) that there’s nothing on my teeth for her to clean off. She even said she wanted to swap places next time so I can clean her teeth. I was always a diligent flosser and brusher with a manual brush, but I never managed to prevent her from having to scrape my gums to oblivion until I got this brush. I love it and I will never switch to another brush.

I've been using the Oral-B Pro 1000 for a little while now, and I've got to say, it's pretty good! My teeth definitely feel cleaner since I switched to using it, and I think my smile is a bit brighter too.The toothbrush is easy to use, which is a big plus for me. It has this one button that turns it on and off, and it sort of pulses every 30 seconds to let you know to move to a different part of your mouth.It also comes with a charger, and the battery life seems pretty decent. I don't have to charge it too often, which is convenient. The design is sleek and looks nice on my bathroom counter, not too bulky or anything.The reason I'm not giving it a full 5 stars is because, while it works great, i don’t love how small the head is and I kind of feel like the proportions are weird in my hand.  Also, I wish it came with more than one brush head to start off with. It would be nice to try out different kinds without having to buy them separately right away.Overall, though, it’s s a solid choice if you're looking to upgrade from a manual toothbrush without getting too fancy. It cleans well, is easy to use, and the charge lasts a while. Definitely a good buy in my book!

reviewTitle: Does a very good job on plaque
reviewDescription: I have always used a standard manual brush.  I was skeptical of electric because it seemed like the little head only moved in short back and forth spins (instead of complete circles) making it less effective.  In addition, I assumed that you could not apply any pressure, or the head would stop moving.My dentist recommended I try one to help with plaque build up that I seem to accumulate quickly on the inside of my lower front teeth.  So, I bought this one (my wife has had one a few years).  Some observations:- It does a very good job keeping plaque off.  I actually started using this brush halfway between dentist appointments.  I found that it could not remove already present plaque (at least not what I had), but that once removed by the dentist, this brush does a great job keeping it off.  Much better than a manual brush.  For that alone I am sold.- The small size is very good for getting around back teeth / wisdom teeth.  It also gets you to focus on a tooth at a time (vs. the sawing motion across many teeth) - which actually took no more time.  Overall, a session might take very slightly longer than manual, but is certainly more thorough.- You can press down pretty hard, and the brush keeps oscillating.  Although, in my experience, there is no need.  I tend to use less pressure than a manual brush.  While the brush head is doing a short back and forth spin (vs. a total 360), that seems just as effective (perhaps more so, since you get both directions of spin very quickly on all surfaces).- The brush does a pulsing vibration after 2 minutes.  You can just ignore it and keep brushing.  It also does much lighter pulses every 30 seconds, to help you time your session into groups of upper front, upper back, lower front, lower back.  Again, you can ignore all this and just brush at your own pace.- If two people in the same bathroom are using this type of brush, there are two good options.  One, have both people use the same base, and just switch out the head (they are color coded for this reason).  Or two, give each person their own unit, but keep just one charging base out.  The charge need is so infrequent, that its easy to just leave one brush standing on its own, and the other on the charger; then just switch out when a charge is needed.  This clears up counter space and cords.- We have purchased the generic (and less expensive) replacement heads.  In our experience, they were identical to the originals in materials and make.  I am sure there is a lot of quality variation, but it was not hard to find good options.- My wife and I have what appear to be identical models, except we did one black, one white to make them easy to keep separate.  Mine, the white, only turns off by pressing the off button 3 times (since it cycles through modes using the on/off button).  This is the only thing I really do not like.  The black one turns off with one click.  Perhaps it is a setting, but we can find no way to change it.  So, I find myself holding the brush in my mouth (to stop splatter) while finding the button (see below), and pressing 3 times.- The on off button is a little hard to press.  It is flush and shallow.  I always manage to get it on and off, but sometimes it is surprisingly hard.  Recently, it would not turn on, and I thought it must have lost its charge.  Turns out I just had to press very firmly.  This can be a challenge when turning the unit off.  You tend to keep it in your mouth (to prevent splatter), and so finding and pressing the button is sometimes a little harder than you would think.  I think for most people, this is just a negative to be accepted.  But for people who are older, or not dexterous in the hands, I think this would actually make the brush impossible to use.Overall, I am happy with it, because it prevents plaque, end of story.  If I could change one thing, it would be a single press, easy press on\off button.

I have an older version of this which was 'softer' to the touch.  This one I did not like at all.  It does what it is supposed to do, which is why I rated it high, but it feels hard and is not as easy to use as the older version.  When I had bought the older version, it came with two units for travel.  I put away the second one as my husband only used a brush.  Years later, now his dentist recommended an electric tooth brush for him, and of course, I could not find where I put it.  I ordered this one for him, and when it came, he didn't find it comfortable to use.  I put it away (I forget where!) and then I found the old one I thought was gone for good.  It has a sort of rubber surface area while this new version is all slick.  It just seems cheaper made to me.  However, it works so it may be just fine for you.

I switched to this after using Philips Sonicare for a very long time.  I used this when I went on vacation and my forgot my toothbrush.  My girlfriend has the Oral B so we only had to buy replacement heads for the trip.  Philips has always worked well but my teeth felt surprising cleaner using the Oral B over the Sonicare.  I bought this model when we returned and have been using it for about 6 months.  The only gripe I have is that the battery dies every couple days and needs recharging.  The charging indicator light never goes out letting you know the battery is fully charged.  It just keeps blinking green like it is still charging even when it is left plugged in overnight.  I will likely buy the more expensive model from Oral B if the battery on that doesn't have the same gripe.  Overall it is a really good toothbrush for the money.

I recently started using the Oral-B Pro 1000 Rechargeable Electric Toothbrush and have found it to be a significant upgrade from manual brushing. The toothbrush offers a range of features that cater to a more efficient and effective oral hygiene routine.Effective Plaque Removal:One of the standout features of the Oral-B Pro 1000 is its ability to remove up to 100% more plaque along the gumline compared to a manual toothbrush. This is largely due to the dentist-inspired round brush head technology, which reaches areas that rectangular manual brushes often miss. The result is a thorough clean that leaves my mouth feeling fresher and cleaner.Gum Protection:The sensi cleaning mode and Gum Pressure Control are excellent additions for anyone concerned about gum health. The toothbrush automatically stops pulsations when brushing too hard, protecting gums from excessive pressure. This feature has given me peace of mind, knowing that I'm cleaning effectively without damaging my gums.User-Friendly Features:The integrated quadrant timer is a game-changer. It alerts me every 30 seconds to change the brushing zone, ensuring an even clean across all areas of my mouth. This feature has helped me maintain a more balanced brushing routine.Brushing Modes and Personalization:With three easy-to-use cleaning modes, the Oral-B Pro 1000 allows for a customizable brushing experience. Additionally, the availability of various brush heads for purchase means I can tailor my brushing to specific needs, such as deep cleaning or gentle cleaning.Design and Size:While the toothbrush is highly functional, the design feels a bit outdated compared to some newer models on the market. Also, the size of the brush head is slightly too big for my mouth, which can make maneuvering around tight spaces a bit challenging.Wish for Improvement:A separate button for changing the vibration frequency would be a welcome improvement. Currently, adjusting the settings requires multiple presses of the same button used to turn off the toothbrush, which can be a bit inconvenient.Conclusion:Overall, the Oral-B Pro 1000 Rechargeable Electric Toothbrush is a solid choice for anyone looking to enhance their oral hygiene routine. Its effective plaque removal, gum protection features, and user-friendly design make it a valuable tool for daily dental care. Despite its slightly bulky size and dated design, the benefits it offers in terms of cleaning efficiency and gum health are significant.

reviewTitle: Works well but handle is very slippery
reviewDescription: Seems to be well made and does a good job of cleaning my teeth. Drawbacks are design issues:(1) The on/off switch is VERY hard to push.  Hard to turn on and sometimes almost impossible to turn off - definitely takes both hands to turn it off.(2) The handle is very slippery.  Would be nice if they would add a knurl to the handle.  I have added a couple strips of hot glue to the handle to make it less slippery.

reviewTitle: Good, but pressure sensor is subtle
reviewDescription: Good toothbrush so far, I bought it from Wirecutter’s recommendation. This toothbrush does indeed have a pressure sensor, but it’s subtle, and the instruction manual does not describe in enough detail how it works, hence the confusion in these reviews. This is from Oral-B’s website:“All our toothbrushes from the Pro 1000 and above include the pressure sensor. These toothbrushes will stop pulsating when pressing too hard, which will feel and sound noticeably different during brushing. By 'pulsation', we are referring to that the brush head itself is moved forward and backwards very quickly, towards and away from the teeth.”If you turn on the toothbrush and push on the stem with your finger (as if brushing too hard) you’ll hear a quiet click, and can feel something disengage inside the brush head (I suspect that’s the “pulsations” disengaging). If you then put the brush in your mouth, and push it too hard against your teeth, you’ll hear the motor get louder/make a slightly different sound. It’s more subtle than I’d like, but that is how the pressure sensor works. It’s a bit of an acquired feeling.Hope this description helps someone, because it’s kind of hard to figure out just from the instruction manual and product page.

reviewTitle: Feels better than the old model
reviewDescription: Overall I think this is better than the old model of the same toothbrush. Easy to use considering it only has one button and the settings could be nice if you want to vary the intensity of your brushing. The heads are cheap enough and there are tons of inexpensive off brands out there for replacements.I personally don’t like having just one button to cycle through the settings since I’ll prefer to just hit the button once to pause brushing, spit, and press it again to resume. It’s just a couple extra button presses now but it’s mildly annoying.I’d say it’s worth it for an inexpensive electric toothbrush. I’d never go back to a regular ol toothbrush at this point.

reviewTitle: So far, seems okay, but charge is short
reviewDescription: Bought this after another brand died after just 2 years. I think the brush head does a decent job, but the charge didn't seem to last very long, and it supposedly has a 2-minute timer but I haven't noticed one. Also did not come with a manual or QR code/URL for an online one.

In spite of the fact that they sent a blue one instead of the green one, this is a nice toothbrush. But it's just an electric toothbrush. I really like the sleek recharging base. I thought about returning it for the green, but it's not part of the "decor" of the bathroom (lol) so it's not worth the trouble. I've only had it a week. If it breaks or quits on me within a year, I'll follow up and edit my review. A $60.00 toothbrush should last a LONG time.

I recently purchased the Oral-B Pro 1000 CrossAction Electric Toothbrush, and I must say I am thoroughly disappointed with my purchase. I decided to give this toothbrush a chance after my old Sonicare finally gave up the ghost, and the reviews I found, including those on Wirecutter, seemed promising. However, my experience with it has been far from satisfactory.First and foremost, the noise level of this toothbrush is incredibly bothersome. It's super noisy, which makes the whole brushing experience rather unpleasant, especially in the early mornings or late at night when you're trying to be considerate of others in your household. The awkwardness in its design also caught me off guard. It feels cumbersome and unwieldy in my hand, making it difficult to maneuver around my mouth comfortably.One of the major drawbacks is the oscillating brush action. It feels jerky and inconsistent, which is not only uncomfortable but also raises concerns about its durability. The timer feature, intended to help you change brushing zones, feels like the toothbrush is about to seize up and die at any moment. It's disconcerting and doesn't inspire confidence in the product's longevity.In hindsight, I regret not investing a bit more money in another Sonicare or a different electric toothbrush brand. The Oral-B Pro 1000 CrossAction has proven to be one of the worst electric toothbrushes I've ever tried, and I'm frustrated that I can't return it since it's now used.In conclusion, I strongly advise against wasting your time and money on the Oral-B Pro 1000 CrossAction Electric Toothbrush. Instead, consider spending a little extra on a Sonicare or exploring other reputable electric toothbrush brands. Your dental hygiene deserves a product that not only works effectively but also provides a comfortable and enjoyable brushing experience, which sadly, the Oral-B Pro 1000 fails to deliver.

I’ve had a hard time writing this review because in one way this toothbrush does a fabulous job of getting my teeth clean; however, I am not happy that after less than two years of use my $50 toothbrush isn’t working. As I said, the brushing part is fabulous and my teeth feel as though I’ve just had a cleaning at the dentist every time I use the brush. The things that I don’t like at all are: One - the continual flashing green light when the toothbrush is charging. I can’t charge my toothbrush in my bathroom due to lack of counter space and so have it in my bedroom. The flashing green light means that I can’t have it charging when I am trying to sleep. A steady “on” light or even better a light that indicates it’s done charging would be a much better design. Two - the toothbrush indicates when it’s time to switch to a different quadrant of the mouth by slowing and then speeding up again. This is very irritating as it interrupts my flow for brushing my teeth. I always spend longer in each quadrant of the mouth and I wish this feature could be turned off if it’s not needed. The WORST thing; however, is that the toothbrush is no longer charging properly. I can’t even get a full brushing done without the brush losing power. Oral B does offer a 2-year warranty and they are willing to repair the toothbrush but that means that I have to send it in to them and then it will take 7 to 10 days before I get it back. I can’t get along without this brush for up to two weeks. When I explained this to the “advisor” at Oral B they were not at all sympathetic and quoted “standard policy”. So, does that mean I should spend another $50 to get a replacement for the weeks that I need to have this brush or will that toothbrush also fail. I wonder how long these toothbrushes actually last because this one has failed in 16 months. Oral B doesn’t seem to care about standing behind their product. In addition, the first time I tried to contact them via the phone, I sat on hold for 28 minutes and then they hung up on me. If you need to contact them, use “chat”. As usual, this huge company (Procter & Gamble) doesn’t seem to care at all about their customers and only about their bottom line

reviewTitle: Impossible to know what mode you're in and it's LOUD
reviewDescription: This was top-rated by NY Times Wirecutter, and I followed their advice without much thought. The only thing I like about it is my teeth feel polished afterward. That said, it's 1) Loud. Really, really loud. I swear it feels like it wants to escape. 2) The modes don't light up on the handle, so I don't know which one I'm actually in, so I choose the one that seems the least violent - this toothbrush "rumbles" unnervingly. 3) You have to reset the mode every single time you use it, there's no memory. So, in order to brush your teeth once, you are pushing the on button, then three more presses to get to mode number 3 (aka "least violent") if that's the one you want and then a fifth time to turn it off. For anyone whose hands don't work super well anymore, it is literally painful to do this repeatedly.So, if you want something that seems to clean your teeth pretty well, don't mind the noise, and don't really care what mode you're in, and have strong hands, you may be perfectly happy with it. As for me, I can't believe I tossed the box immediately thinking "What could go wrong? It's a toothbrush." Now I'm out $40 + tax.

reviewTitle: A Stuttering Jack Hammer for your teeth.
reviewDescription: I despised everything about this monstrosity.  It has a smooth body offering no grip at all.  If your hand or the body of the toothbrush is wet it slips about. It is not a good idea to try and regain your grip while the thing is actually in your mouth or you might discover a new method of lobotomy. You can not find the power button without taking the toothbrush out of your mouth because it is also smooth and level with the toothbrush body and difficult to find due to the aforementioned slippery situation and unless you want your bathroom decor to be dental speckle I really can't recommend doing this.There are supposed to be multiple power settings but the only one my toothbrush had was "Let's see if your brain has the same shock absorbancy of a woodpecker." My brain does not.There is also supposed to be a "quad sensor" which is supposed to be aware of you long you have been brushing one section of your mouth and then give a little skip to tell you when it is time to move onto another part of your mouth.  Yeah...no.  Oh, it skipped and stuttered alright, when ever it pleased with no rhyme or reason.  This would cause the toothbrush to jerk and your hand to slip which would make the button hard to find and see above for the rest of it.I wrestled with this thing for three days because I was convinced I was doing it wrong, I mean this is an Oral B, I've used this brand my whole life, how could they have screwed up this badly?  It finally got to the point where my mouth was feeling rather sore and I just could not get myself to give it another go.  So, I sent it back.I  can say that it wasn't entirely awful.  Your teeth will be clean.  Really, really, clean.

Before you buy this brush, search the reviews for "MOLD". This brush is a safety hazard! Do not purchase!There is a fatal design flaw in the brush heads that this toothbrush requires. There are two cavities in the brushhead that allow organic material and water to become trapped inside. Eventually, even if you disassemble, clean, and dry after each use, you WILL get a buildup of black mold inside the brush; black mold that goes INSIDE YOUR MOUTH.The photo was taken after running water through the holes and then tapping the brush head on the sink. All the black dots you see are BLACK MOLD that came out of the the brush head.If you contact Oral B support, they will tell you that this is somehow not covered under their warranty.Are you kidding me? Do not buy this product. My recommendation would be to spend a bit more on a brush that doesn't have holes/mold-traps built in, like the Sonicare.

I’m probably overly critical of consumer products in general these days as they all seem designed for the landfills. So take this for what it’s worth…The battery eventually died on my old one that was identical to my wife’s (pictured between mine and my daughter’s here). I have an 8 year old who was super excited to get a “grown up” toothbrush, so I got her the kid version of ours. Then, since she and my wife both have white ones, I simply wanted a black version of the same toothbrush. Cause… well I just like black! And why not match my suite of Manscaping tools!Turns out, that was more complicated than I thought. This brush was my third black toothbrush from this company trying to find one that wasn’t just slippery plastic (the other models didn’t have the nice rubber grip). Though I had many recommendations in favor of other brands, I wanted us all to be able to use the same charger.This toothbrush is fatter than my old one, so it doesn’t feel as nice to hold. It shows white residue all over it no matter how much I rinse and clean it. I’m a shower brusher, so you’d think it would be easy to rinse (See aforementioned Manscaped products that are designed very well).In addition, it turns out they don’t have the same brush tip choices in black either. So yeah… black was a fail!Lastly… I’m not sure what device-dependent world makes anyone “need” an app to brush their teeth, but hey, I gave it a shot. Not convinced AT ALL that any of these modes are doing anything different for my teeth except maybe the gentler mode for the gums. But the app didn’t accurately pick up areas that I was brushing and requires you to actually grab your phone and turn the app on to utilize its features. With no plans to jump out of the shower or start my app before I get in… this is pretty useless.Overall this is an overpriced gimmick for those who really just want everything they use to feel high tech!K.I.S.S.Keep Is Simple Stupid! :-)

This toothbrush stopped rotating the brush head after 5 months. I was disappointed with it to begin with for two big reasons - - the instructions that came with it didn't match up with the Type number (3791) so I want able to figure out what multiple presses of the different buttons does. Also, a huge engineering flaw in my mind--when setting the toothbrush on the counter, it rolls! There are two tiny dots on the underside that are supposed to support it but obviously they aren't big enough so it's constantly rolling around and getting toothpaste on my counter.

reviewTitle: Per oral b: needs a 22 hour charge time!!!! I hate it. Should have bought another Phillips sonicare.
reviewDescription: Update: I called them since they have a money back guarantee and they only honor this if you still have the box. Who keeps a box to a toothbrush. I complained to the rep about the battery not lasting longer than a week when my sonicare lasted like a month. He informed me it’s a 22 hour charge time!!!!! What a joke!!!!I accidentally broke my sonicare that I had for a long time and my husbands had stopped holding a charge (we’d had them for a long time). I should have bought what I knew I liked. This oral b holds a charge for less than half the time the Phillips did. Maybe a week. My other one could go weeks. Also, I hate hate hate the on/off button. It’s hard to press. It doesn’t warn you when the battery is low!!!!!!!!

reviewTitle: It's not quite what it's described as
reviewDescription: UPDATE 2: Returned as defective. On the second charge, it took much longer than the advertised 22 hrs, and battery died within seconds of first use.UPDATE 1: I'm bumping this up to 4 stars for two reasons (original review below): 1) I like this just as much as my Phillips, and if I'm willing to give that 3.5-4 stars, I ought to give this 3.5-4 stars too; 2) Now that I'm looking for it, there is indeed a 2-minute timer.  It's a shame that I have to pay special attention to it, but it is definitely different from the 30-second timer.  I'd give this a 3.5 if I could, but since I'm feeling guilty about the original 3 stars, I'll go ahead and bump this up to a 4.A few days into using the toothbrush, and I rather like it.  I was afraid it would be too loud based on other reviews, but it seems quieter than my previous Phillips Sonicare.  The rotary action also does seem to clean better and isn't as abrasive as I thought it would be.  So why three stars only?  For me, I think it ordinarily would've been rated 4 to 4.5 stars, but I'm a little annoyed at two things which are used to market the Pro1000, so I've docked a star.First, they advertise that there is a 2 minute timer.  On the Oral-B website, it says: "The electric toothbrush also alerts you when you have brushed for the dentist-recommended time of 2 minutes." I'll have to pay extra attention to it but I haven't noticed that it's markedly different from the 30 second timer.  Not a big deal, I can just keep track of 4x 30 seconds, but since this is marketed as a feature, it'd be great if it were more prominent.  I'm told that the 2 minute stutter is longer than the 3- second stutter, so will look out for it.  This feature is probably there, and I just haven't noticed, but that's still noteworthy that it wasn't obvious. In comparison, the Phillips would turn off after 2 minutes.Second, they advertise a pressure sensor. On the Oral-B website, it says: "Pressure Sensor: Slows and stops pulsations if you brush too hard."  The key thing to note here is that the brush doesn't just pulsate.  It also rotates and may oscillate.  So, assuming the pulsations actually stop, then you are still damaging your teeth while brushing because the other motions continue.  For me, I think this effectively negates the value of having the pressure sensor in the first place.  If this is feature is important to you, look for a model that gives you a indicator light that you're brushing too hard so that you can manually adjust.Again, for both of these features, they didn't technically misrepresent; still the product's not quite what I expected.

1. Mimicking the crazy design philosophy developed by Apple in which many needed actions are hidden or disguised, so was the On/Off button. I have the 2006 version of this and the button was deeply recessed thus easy to access.2. It requires 3 presses of the hard-to-find button to turn the motor off, and they are hard presses.3. If you intend to hold  the product while you brush your teeth, plan on using something to grip it, like a  non-slip pad of some sort, as it quickly becomes slippery and unmanageable. The 2006 version used a non-slip exterior unlike this one. Got to admit, however, it looks nice in photographs and that's what is important in today's Instagram world.Back it goes to the seller.

reviewTitle: 3rd Oral-B toothbrush this week that doesn't work.
reviewDescription: This is the 3rd Oral-B toothbrush I have tried this week that doesn't work. This brush is loud. No pressure sensor; it doesn't stop when you brush too hard. I pushed hard to test it. Nothing happened. It doesn't stop automatically when the 2 minutes is up. I kept wondering when it was going to stop and finally just shut it off. I bought the next model up as well, I forget what it is called, but it was the $77 one. It didn't stop when the time was up either. Now I have to return both. I want to buy this toothbrush, it has good reviews, but it would be great if it operated properly. I checked the "oscillating, rotating" claim with a piece of floss. This brush does not rotate(spin.) This brush slightly oscillates. So if you wanted a toothbrush that spins, as I do, this one does not. And apparently it isn't a fluke, because I bought 3 and tried each one. $40 for a brush that just vibrates, very loudly at that, is a bit much. What is happening to quality?

When I ordered this toothbrush after using quip for years I thought I would be delighted with a smaller head and sleek design but no this thing is noisy like a jackhammer and the bristles stop spinning when slight pressure is applied. I am disappointed with this product.

Opened it up and set it up and it wouldn't turn on.... Waited thinking it needed to charge. Never worked. I already threw the box out. Amazon won't just send a replacement, so my only option is going through the manufacturer website which is broken... Wish I could give 0 stars

reviewTitle: Rechargeable battery would not hold a charge after a few days
reviewDescription: The toothbrush showed the red flashing light that indicated it needed to be charged after being turned off following a session of brushing within a week of receiving it.

Toothbrush is too long , hand slides down near the top when it gets wet, too slippery when brushing,power off button is hard to find while brushing, the original vitality or pro series much better, Al least it had a grip on it, they always change things when they shouldn’t

reviewTitle: Producto salió defectuoso y no obtuve el reemplazo....
reviewDescription: La verdad es una decepción cuando uno recibe un producto defectuoso como es el caso y Amazon no te da la opción de reemplazar u obtener un reembolso. El producto desde el primer día de uso no quiere cargar completamente, lo dejo por 6-8 horas cargando y no consigo que lo haga. Y al usar solo dilata 3 usos. Es normal que funcione así?

reviewTitle: its stopped working in one month, its difficult to get money back
reviewDescription: its stopped working in one month, its difficult to get money backits not chargeable

I bought this toothbrush because I need to be more conscientious about how hard I press when I brush.  This toothbrush is advertised as having a pressure sensor, but there is no clear indication when you are pressing too hard. The instructions say that it makes a different sound when you are pressing too hard, but there was no clear audible difference in my opinion.
I bought this product and six weeks later it will not hold a charge.

This is my 4th or 5th Oral-B/Braun toothbrush in 20 years of using electric toothbrushes. Never have I been so disappointed. I bought this one because my last one was getting old and the battery wasn’t lasting long enough for my trips. The advertising says 10 days of battery life. I’m lucky if I get 4 uses before it dies. This last charge lasted all of 2 1/2 brushes before it died. Unacceptable. I’ll have to replace it and it’s barely 2 months old.

Bought one if these a year ago that never charged correctly. Returned and bought another one. After several months of use, past the refund time frame, 2nd one stopped  charging as well.  Believe they may be knock - offs.  Buyer beware.

reviewTitle: Loud, difficult to use, I don't like it at all.
reviewDescription: 1.  Extremely loud and rattles2.  Not a pleasant experience to brush my teeth; the handle is cumbersome, the brush, too big, and the timer is just wierd- one pause, four stacatto beats, then two....Will be purchasing a different brand asap

I have had this product for less than a year and it will not charge anymore. I know it’s not the charger bc my husband has the same one and his will charge on my charger. I contacted the company and they told me about the two year warranty except when I enter the product information on the website it says “ the product does not exist or is no longer in service.” So I can’t complete the process and the chat agent advised to “ just keep refreshing my page until works bc it works fine for her.”The product also smells bad. My husband’s and mine both stink. The part of the toothbrush that you hold smells musky even after cleaning it etc. I’m not please with the quality, customer service, or durability of this product and will not be repurchasing.

reviewTitle: worked great for a month, then died on me
reviewDescription: really happy with the cleaning but jeez, one month of regular use and the thing mysteriously croaks? I don't think my mouth presents such a hazardous environment this poor machine would have to hang em up for good.
I returned because cord had a cut..but this model is also more slippery than others I have used in the past. The handle is very slick when wet...would go with another option that has a grip
First there was no timer on this toothbrush. Next it was so extremely loud, and lastly, it would slow down to the point of stopping and then struggle to start up again. I returned it.

Not very powerful, loud and sounds like it’s on its last leg, even though it’s new and fully charged. I miss my Sonicare toothbrush, will continue to get some use out of this one, and I’m not sure it’s much better than manual. Can’t wait to buy a Sonicare again! Sonicare for life lol! Very disappointed in OralB.
have had other Oral B electric toothbrushes so choice was easy. within a few weeks battery compartment leaked- thought itvwas bad battery but changing them had same result. Too late to return it.

reviewTitle: Not For Me, Too Much Vibration
reviewDescription: I thought getting an electric toothbrush would be ideal for a deeper clean but does not seem much better than manual. Personally, I am not a fan of how this brush makes my teeth feel while brushing. There is too much vibration even on the lowest setting. It’s kind of uncomfortable and getting the top teeth is the worst. I honestly feel like a get a better clean manually.

So this toothbrush is exactly what I expected when I ordered it, and it does clean teeth very well, but I'm leaving this review in protest, hoping that it makes it's way to some engineer or marketing specialist at Oral-B.The toothbrush is almost identical in function to the one I got years ago, so I know what problems it has. First is the battery, it's a Ni-Cd battery. These have less capacity than Li-ion batteries and can develop "memory" and reduce their capacity if you recharge them before they're empty. The batteries are not replaceable and will be the first part to wear out. If the batteries could be replaced and were Li-ion, it would be less electronic waste and maybe make the price tag reasonable.Next is the charger. It's wireless in that there is no plug that connects to the toothbrush. However the charger is always on when it's plugged in, wasting electricity and overcharging the battery. It's almost like they intentionally designed the toothbrush to burn itself out after a year of use. I use an outlet switch so I can turn off the charger saving power and the battery.As far as the other features for, it cleans teeth great. Just wish it could have decent design otherwise.
This thing sucks and the functionality is sub-par compared to other electric toothbrushes. I don’t buy, upgrade from this base model trash.

This toothbrush has several design flaws. It is VERY noisy, does not stay flat on counter if using 2 hands to squeeze toothpaste out, timer is hard to notice, does not shut off automatically, hard to shut off.  You have to push the on/off button several times to shut off. If you take it out of your mouth before shutting it off, IT SPRAYS toothpaste and spit all over the place.  Very dissatisfied with this product.
Just today I returned this specific model because of 2 reasons.  First, mine did not have 3 modes. It has only 1. Secondly, Towards the end or brushing my teeth, it became very slippery.
Purchased in August of 2023 and 5 months later it’s broken. No longer charges.  I would not buy this again.

reviewTitle: Repeat Purchase: not the same product as before
reviewDescription: I was very happy with this product when i bought it two years ago.  It suddenly stopped working so I juts thought I'd buy a new one.  They are obviously now using cheaper materials, it feels really plasticy.  The brush now seems so much more aggressive and leaves my mouth feeling roughed up!  but worst of all the off button seems really hard to find when you want to turn it off (I know this sounds silly) but even worse, you have to tap it THREE times to turn it off.  Terrible experience each time.  I'd return this if I still had the box, I didn't expect it to be any different to the one I bought previously

I’ve owned more expensive Oral-b toothbrushes, so I can say this one is not their best. Not much power to this one and it’s incredibly hard to turn off. Also, the battery life isn’t strong. Spend a bit more money and buy one of their nicer models.
This is the 2nd Oral-B electric toothbrush that stopped working after just a few months of using it.Very disappointing!!!

reviewTitle: Sounds and feels like a jackhammer
reviewDescription: Not impressed. Very loud and clunky
The on button very temporarily works
It’s loud, rough and you have to hit the button 3 times to turn it off.  Returning.
Effectively cleans between teeth and at the unlike. It is noisy and the motor loads down if you turn the brushead to any angle it doesn’t like.
This toothbrush is bulky and loud. However the battery life is very good.
A mi hija le gustó, tiene temporizador pero no indicador de fuerza en el cepillado, lo cual me decepcionó porque decía que este modelo lo tenía.

I've been surprised with how quickly I've gotten used to using an electric toothbrush versus a manual one. I feel like it's making a solid difference how in how clean my teeth are. So now my complaints. 1) It's loud. Louder than I expected. If that bothers you, don't buy this one. 2) I wish it automatically shut off when that two minutes were up. This complaint is nitpicky and isn't so much of an issue as that's just my preference. Otherwise, I think was definitely worth the money.
The dentist recommended  this electric brush.  My spouse lives it and I am adjusting to using it.  It works really well.
This works just as well for a fraction of the price

I went to the dentist and they suggested an electric toothbrush since i’ve always use a manual and has braces, found this one to highly rated and not to expensive and it works amazingly! it has 3 different setting for deep clean, gentle and gums. it also has a gentle timer for your teeth when to move to the other side of your mouth and then buzzes for when the 2 minutes are up. I also like that it’s rechargeable and has long battery life. i enjoy it and it’s worth the money for basic effective cleaning, i’ve noticed a difference already when i go to bed and wake up my teeth don’t feel as dirty!sorta cons: it’s kinda loud but i’ve never used a electric toothbrush so idk if that’s just something i’m not used to and it also makes a weird sounds sometimes.
Like the brushing results. Doesn't have a working timer. Poor imstructions.
Cleans wellNoisyExpected automatic shut offOverall happy with it
You have to hit the off switch multiple times to turn it off. Previous versions turned of with the first tap. This is inconvenient.

For some reason it doesn’t feel as powerful as the 100 battery operated version made by the same brand, but the shape of the brush head and the way the brush rotates has given me a superior cleaning to any other brand of toothbrush that I’ve found to date.

reviewTitle: On/off button hard to push.  Otherwise, great!
reviewDescription: This is my fourth Oral B electric toothbrush.  They have all functioned well and lasted a long time.  Have owned everything from $40-$140 versions.When I saw that the more expensive brushes now require proprietary (and different) changers and heads, I was fine to go with a lower-end toothbrush.  I don’t use the fancier features on the more expensive brushes, anyway.But for some reason, this particular brush has an on-off button that is hard to press.  I have no hand mobility issues and have tried holding it different ways, but it usually takes 2+ presses to turn it on or off.I’d suggest getting a different Oral B model.

I bought this for Christmas, priced them in the retail stores, drug stores and online. I wanted the oral B brand. There are wide ranges of prices, but this was online for around 30- or so, give or take a few dollars. I also bought the pro 500 for 16-. The extra 15 dollars is for the toothbrush to recharge, really, it's the same toothbrush, not as fancy as io brushes, has the timer and access to the oral B site, which offers tutorials on how to brush, connections to the cell phone and coupons for replacement brush heads, toothpaste, etc.

Decent price for this.  Not aware of any timer function.  The only thing that I don’t care for is the “on/off” pad.  Not confident that this will last.  Seems more cheaply made, not easy to press on/off.

Likes:- It had a good price point- It fits all the existing heads that I had purchased for one that I used for 8 years- Compact and does the jobDislikes:- The on / off button I have to hit several times to actually turn it off- I had a much older version of this (8 yrs old) and it felt better madeOverall it does the job, but I just feel like this one isn't going to last 8 years like the other one did.

reviewTitle: I bought this a month ago and it does not work

Husband thinks it is great. He loves it. Had some bad reviews but purchased it anyway. So far so good.

reviewTitle: It brushes well but it is loud
reviewDescription: I had an off brand electronic toothbrush that didn't last a year before it stopped working. I decided to get name brand, highly reviewed and recommended toothbrush. It brushes really well, sometimes a little too hard on the gums but thats on me. What I wasn't prepared for was how much louder it would be! It is annoying.

reviewTitle: Brushes well but some odd quirks.
reviewDescription: I was used to the Philips Sonicare, some of my comments are influenced by this experience.Many reviews described the device as noisy. I found it not as noisy as I was made to expect.This brushes well, like a traditional tooth brush on steroid. Very different from the Sonicare, which works with vibration, not abrasion. No idea which is better, but I am comfortable with how this one worksThe documentation advertised the same quadrant timer feature as the Sonicare, but it never triggered for me. Not a problem: I was not a big fan of that timer, it stressed me out.To stop the brush is a bit weird: one tap slows it down, a second tap slows it even more, a third stops it. If I just keep pressing, it quickly slows and the stop. I still have to get used to it, but I would not consider it a defect.I am happy overall, but I am still not used to this device's multiple quirks.
Comfortable to use and cleans great down to the gums. My only complaint is that the on/off button is very difficult to use.

reviewTitle: I kind of hate it, but it DOES clean teeth
reviewDescription: The feature ratings are- Deep Cleaning: 5- Timer Function: 3- Bluetooth connectivity: 1I'll address those in turn, then address the title.Deep Cleaning: jeez is this thing effective. You have two different intensities, depending on how hard you press the brush against your teeth. I use it in tandem with a rigorous flossing routine and a hard bristle brush for large debris removal. It offers a genuinely clean feeling (like I just got out of the hygienist's chair) most of the time, with me just paying mind to the timer.Timer Function: you'll get a hard-to-miss vibration every 30 seconds. One "play" of this sequence for every quadrant of your mouth to guide your cleaning, with the fourth being more pronounced, to tell you "you're done" (with the dentist recommended 2-minutes of brushing). It's solid but has significant shortcomings.1. If you stop brushing before you finish the cycle-of-4 (or if you brush for longer), the brush isn't smart enough to know that. There doesn't seem to be an internal "smart reset" mechanism, and there is no means of manually triggering such except to let the brush run and to turn it off as soon as you hear/feel the 4th-cycle pattern.2. There are occasions when the brush seems to be smart enough to detect *something* about restart the *count* to 4, but it doesn't reset the 30-sec timer. That's just strange.So why 3 stars? Because I've bought cheaper tooth brushes that are more consistent (e.g. just turning off the motor after the cycle-of-4) with their timers' behavior. This one does more, but inconsistently, and was more expensive. 3 star value for 3 star functionality.Bluetooth: functionality doesn't exist. No idea what they're talking about.The Title: why do I "hate" it? Water capture. Water, and tooth-pasty saliva, get caught in the weirdest places in this brush, such that I can rarely complete a brushing without much of it trickling down my hand, wrist, and arm. Might I also mention that I have to store the brush head on a towel, so the trapped water will flow out in a managed space, rather than caking (e.g.) the brush with tooth-pasty water spots? The only mitigation I've found is a near-constant inhalation as means of suctioning the moisture to stay in my mouth. This is the first electric toothbrush with which I've had this problem. The dripping effect varies from brush head to brush head (which need to be swapped rather often, especially if you are undergoing orthodontia) which suggests a manufacturing quality-control issue.I would not buy it again, knowing this is what I was getting into. I wish it wasn't the case, because you can tell they tried to make something quality, but effort and execution are different things.If someone could prove to me that it's just faulty hardware or my poor technique, I would gladly improve the rating.

reviewTitle: Too Hard on the Hands - Gave Up After One Month
reviewDescription: I don't leave reviews unless something really stands out. This toothbrush is fine for my teeth. But it's TERRIBLE on my hands. My old Oral-B spinbrush lasted well over a decade and I bought this as a replacement when it finally died. After less than a month, I am ordering a replacement. This will wind up in the trash because...1. It's too hard to hold. If you are a senior, have compromised hand strength, nerve issues, pain - or any hand issues - this is not the toothbrush for you. My old toothbrush handle was covered in a thin layer of some sort of rubber-like coating that gave it some grip. This new brush is completely slippery. It has some little design-element dimples in it but they do nothing to help the grip. Add in water and toothpaste and this is really hard to hold. And it's hard to brush your teeth well when you don't have a consistent grip on the handle to turn it to reach various tooth surfaces. I can't understand why whoever designed this thought a shiny smooth plastic handle was a design improvement over something so obviously more functional.2. The power button is slightly indented instead of sticking out. For me, it's almost impossible to feel on a slippery wet handle with some toothpaste foam on it. And when I do find it - it's very hard to press to turn it off. It usually takes several tries.After using this for less than a month, I gave up and ordered an Oral B Vitality FlossAction that's half the price, has a surface with grip, a stick-out power button, and a timer that automatically turns it off after 2 minutes. I'm hoping this will be better for my hands.

reviewTitle: Weirdly drippy, dumb controls, and short battery life
reviewDescription: I ordered this after using a spinbrush with rechargeable AA batteries for several years, and then using some cheapo sonic toothbrush for a while. I thought it would be great in comparison due to Oral B being an actual brand and it being fairly expensive.Wow was I wrong. Reasons I hate this thing and am getting rid of it:1. I don't know if it's my mouth shape, brushing technique, or what, but this thing always tends to drip along the back and I always end up with a gross trickle of toothpaste-spit on my hand and on the handle.2. The controls are dumb. It has 3 different speeds. Even the cheap generic sonic brush I had would remember your last speed and just default to that. I'd click to turn it on, click to turn it off. You could change speed by double clicking. Great! But not this POS. You have to cycle through all the speeds every time. You can at least turn it off by holding down the button for a couple of seconds, but COME ON. WHY? Really dumb controls.3. The battery only lasts less than 2 weeks, brushing 2x per day. That seems really short? My previous 2 brushes were weeks, maybe months, between recharging. Minor inconvenience, but still annoying that after a week the thing is already slowing down. I could have left it on a charger all the time but I like my vanity to be tidier than that, and don't think I should have to have a cable management system for a gd toothbrush.Anyway, I left it 2 stars because it's a working electric toothbrush, but I'm tempted to give it a 1. Will not be buying replacement heads, or any other oral b toothbrush ever again.

reviewTitle: The charging system on this brush is the ABSOLUTE WORST!
reviewDescription: This was my first time buying and using an electric toothbrush.  The package arrived promptly (as usual), and contained the toothbrush (the handle and the single included brushhead are separated), a small leaflet with instructions in multiple languages, a coupon and registration instructions and a charger.  The toothbrush did not have any charge when it arrived, and so, I plugged in the charger and put my brush handle on it to charge while I read the instructions.The instructions do say that it may take a while for the charging indicator to start blinking when the charge is low.  It took 30 minutes for the light to start blinking (I was quite close to assuming that the product was DOA and was about to pack it up for a return), and then it took 20 hours for it to finish charging (the charging indicator goes off when it is fully charged).Before I rant about the charger, let me say that the brush itself works pretty well.  Assembling the head onto the handle is trivial (except for the stupid ring that, for some reason, is separate from the brushhead instead of being part of it, so that you can drop it while trying to slip it on and go after it on your hands and knees - whoever designed this must be an idiot or sadist).  The brush is not silent.  I measured it at between 30 and 40 decibels using an app on my phone.  And it sounds louder than that when you put it inside your mouth and turn it on!As the instructions indicate, the brush pauses every 30 seconds after you turn it on so that you remember to move the brush from one quadrant of your mouth to another.  At the end of 2 minutes, it pauses and stutters a lot more to let you know that you should be done.  There is no way to turn off the timer or adjust its timings.  I have taken to ignoring the timer and brushing my teeth until I feel I have done the job thoroughly.  I feel that 30 seconds per quadrant when each quadrant has three surfaces to clean (outside, inside and chewing surface) per tooth is a little too rushed.  Thankfully, the brush does not stop running at the end of the timer, so you can ignore the timer without having to switch the brush on at the end of two minutes.The brush also has a pressure sensor so, if you press down too hard on your teeth, the brush turns off.  In this model, the on/off switch just switches on or off the brush.  On more advanced models (the user manual does not make this clear at all), the on/off switch cycles the brush through multiple brushing modes also.  The brushhead has special bristles that lose color as you use them, so when they lose all their color, you know to replace the brushhead.  A set of 3 replacement brushheads is about $20.  In all likelihood, you will need at least 3 or 4 brushheads per year, so take that into account when you figure out the long-term cost of this brush.Now, back to the charger.  This brush uses some kind of wireless charging technology, probably as part of making the toothbrush waterproof.  My shaver is wet and dry one that can be used in the shower, and it has a regular charger that plugs into the shaver without any issues.  And it charges the shaver (which has a much larger battery than this toothbrush) in about one hour from 0 to 100%.  This brush takes 15 minutes to start charging, and it charges endlessly.  After two days of use, I charged the brush again, and it took more than 16 hours to charge up fully.And on top of this stupidly slow design, the charger will only accept 110 - 130 volts input.  You cannot travel internationally with this charger unless you not only carry an outlet adapter for the pins, but also an actual transformer to get the voltage down to 110 volts from the 220 to 240 volts used in many other countries.  In this day and age, this is nothing but criminally greedy behavior on the part of Oral B to try and sell more of these useless chargers to people just to enable them to travel internationally.  And the rechargeable battery is not user-replaceable either.I WOULD DEFINITELY NOT RECOMMEND THIS PRODUCT.  Oral B needs to fix this insanely long trickle-charging process.  And they need to come out with a charger that will accept 100 to 240 volts, 50/60 Hz input.

reviewTitle: I really wanted to like this, but too many negatives.
reviewDescription: I have used the Phillips sonicare for years.  It finally stopped working and I had to decide whether to spend the hundreds of dollars to buy another or switch brands and go with oral b. The price tag of around  $100 for the oral b vs $300 or more for the Phillips convinced me to try the oral b. Also the replacement  brushes are much more expensive with  the phillips. The oral  b arrived hygenically sealed and was packaged well.Now for the negatives and positives of both brands,  1). The Phillips wasn't packaged as well, even though the price was much higher on the Phillip's.  2)  The Phillip's heads fit my mouth perfectly, where as the heads on the oral b were just too large.  3)  I felt like I was driving  a Kia with the Oral-B,  and felt like I was driving a Toyota with the Phillips. The Phillips is intuitive and not at all cumbersome. I felt like water and toothpaste were spraying everywhere with the oral b.  The Phillip's is just more sleek!4)  the worst thing on the oral b is the button that turns the unit on and off.  I have no idea if the brush is supposed to turn itself off. I couldn't find anything about it in the directions. So far,  it has never turned off on its own.  Maybe that's because it's so annoying that I have to interject and manually turn it off before my time is up.  And that leads to another big negative. You don't just push an easy button to turn it off. It has to go through 5 or so levels of painful finger pushing to get the thing to turn off.  I do not understand why!  It probably does an ok job,  but with a face full of foam and a non focused brush, I find myself not looking forward to brushing my teeth. Also the oral b hurts. Not like I need to toughen up my gums, but rather like it's just too large and hitting areas it shouldn't.5)  Since I purchased my Phillips  sonicare many years ago, they have come out with many different brushes. I spent hours trying to figure out which one was right for me.  I got so fed up with their non user friendly descriptions  I gave up and purchased the oral b. I will keep it because I've already used it,  but maybe it will turn into an expensive cleaning tool for around the sink and faucets. It also seems louder and certainly more clumsy than the sonicare. I have to say,  I miss my Phillips sonic care.

reviewTitle: There are 3 model Pro-1000; this isn't the best one. Quit workng after 2 months
reviewDescription: The majority of research on electric toothbrushes has the Oral B Pro-1000 coming out on top of all competitors almost every time.  The Amazon Prime Day Deal of only $39.99 made me jump at this one. My old one (basic model) wasn't charging well anymore, so I got the new one.Come to find out, there are 3 Pro-1000 models, 2 of which have nifty features and a whole other level of clean/settings. This middle-of-the-road model is type 3757. It does have 3 cleaning modes, but darned if I know what/where  they are. It does make a slightly different vibrational noise when you click the power button the 2nd & 3rd times, but there's nothing written in any manual about this specific one and what that means.Sometimes the brush makes a terrible, gutteral vibration sound. I have to turn it off and on again for it to go away.UPDATED  REVIEW: Dec. 20, 2023Just the other day, my toothbrush would not turn on at all, no matter where I pushed the power button. My arthritis in my thumb area is hurting to the point where I can't really use this toothbrush anymore. I wish it had pooped out during the return period. Sheesh. I suggest you get this a retail.

Have had Oral B electric toothbrushes for forever.  They are terrific and my dentist is consistently thrilled with my check-ups.  That being said, my toothbrushes died recently.  They were 8 years old.  Purchased 2 new ones and find the "on/off button" is amazingly difficult to engage.  WTH?  Both my husband and I are having the same problem so it isn't operator error.  The on buttons are terribly unresponsive.  You have to really push your nail directly into the center of the button for to turn on (or off) and that usually takes several tries.  Will need to see if I can return.  I stupidly threw the boxes out assuming Oral B would provide a superior product.  Buyer beware!

Not much to like for me. This toothbrush is very loud and rough. And my teeth don't feel as clean as they did with my old cheap sonic one. The on/off switch is awkward to use (the button isn't easy to push and you need to push it 4 times to turn it off). It doesn't hold a charge very long (yes, we charged it for 24 hours before using). I don't like the charging stand- I prefer a separate small charger that plugs into the bottom (and only needs charged every 2 weeks). The final straw is it only came with one head, and the 3-head package at the grocery store was $30 which my husband bought before we realized how much we hated the toothbrush. The only potential upside is that some reviewers say this one lasts for years (not helpful if you don't like it) and the sonic ones seem to die after a year and a half.

reviewTitle: WARNING - 3 recent purchases had bad batteries
reviewDescription: I have used this toothbrush for many years.  One lasted almost 5 years, the next one a bit over 2 years.  So I ordered another one when my old one barely kept a charge.  This first one I received was DOA.  Did not work out of the box even though I put it on the charger overnight.  The next one lasted about two days.  Fabulous reviews - justified in my experience - made my hopefully order a third.  Worked great the first day, needed some charge the next day.  Totally dead the day after.Braun - you have a problem.  Buyer beware.

My rechargeable toothbrush - the other leading brand - finally gave up the ghost. I planned on buying the same brand but they inexplicably replaced the wall plug with a usb (!). I bought this product instead having heard of the brand and the manufacturer (Braun). I should have dealt with the USB challenge instead.The Oral B toothbrush is heavier, louder and less comfortable to use. The brush head is larger and the overall design just seems poorly thought out. Even the process of turning the brush on/off is more difficult. I’ll probably continue to use this until the head needs replaced and toss it.

Update #2: I know the Pro 1500 isn't on Oral-B's website. When I bought the Pro 1500 nearly a year ago, I asked Oral-B why it's not on their site because I was concerned I had just bought a discontinued product. They assured me that it was in fact a brand new item that they had just released and that they were going to add the Pro 1500 to their site "soon".I realize that it's nearly a year later and they still haven't done it even though they are still manufacturing it, but I have been to their site several times per month since then and I can tell you that I'm honestly not surprised it's not on their site yet. I get the impression that anyone could do a better job with their site up-keep than whoever is doing it now. I have even noticed that it's kinda somewhat falling apart. Some elements no longer work and haven't worked for months. Their products are fine, they just need better people to handle and operate their website.Update #1: When I wrote this review, the price was the same for the Pro 1000 and Pro 1500 (including both the black and white Pro 1000s). Today, the price for the Pro 1500 nearly $20 more than it was when I wrote this review, and currently close to $30 more than the Pro 1000.[Original review below]I bought this to replace a very new Vitality. It was a *HUGE* upgrade over the Vitality, but then I saw the Pro 1500 and learned from Oral-B that it's quite superior. The Pro 1000's specs are:- 1 cleaning mode: Daily Clean- 8,800 oscillations per minute and 20,000 pulsations per minute on the Daily Clean mode- A pressure sensor that's supposed to just stop the pulsations when it's triggered- A pro timer that hesitates the motor once every 30 seconds, and 3 times every 2 minutes- A NiMH battery (old technology)- A battery life of 28 minutes (7 days, 2 minutes per day 2 times per day)- A full recharge time of 22 hours- A green charge indicator LED that blinks while charging, but stays off when it's not charging- A red battery level indicator that blinks a few times upon on/off if the battery needs to be charged- The CrossAction brush headThe Pro 1500's specs are:- 2 cleaning modes: Daily Clean and Sensitive- 9,900 oscillations per minute and 45,000 pulsations per minute on the Daily Clean mode (these speeds are faster than any I've seen so far in the specs of any of Oral-B's electric toothbrushes, including the Genius 8000 - they all seem to top out at 8,800 oscillations per minute and 40,000 pulsations per minute)- 7,400 oscillations per minute and 33,000 pulsations per minute on the Sensitive mode- A pressure sensor using a red LED that turns on when the pressure sensor is triggered- A pro timer that hesitates the motor once every 30 seconds, and 3 times every 2 minutes- A Lithium Ion battery- A battery life of 56 minutes (14 days, 2 minutes per day 2 times per day)- A full recharge time of 12 hours- A green charge indicator LED that blinks while charging, but stays off when it's not charging- A red battery level indicator that blinks a few times upon on/off if the battery needs to be charged.- The CrossAction brush headThe Vitality is extremely basic:- 1 cleaning mode: Daily Clean- 7,600 oscillations per minute.- A timer that hesitates the motor 3 times every 2 minutes- A NiMH battery- A battery life of 20 minutes (5 days, 2 minutes per day 2 times per day)- A full recharge time of 19 hours- No charge indicators or battery life indicators- Mine came with the Sensitive Gum Care brush headIn comparison, the Vitality seems like a cheap generic electric toothbrush. Don't consider buying it.When I upgraded to the Pro 1000, it was amazing. I wanted to burst at the seams and write an extremely rave review, but then I learned about *and ordered* the Oral-B Pro 1500. After using it, I can tell you that the Pro 1500 is *FAR* better than the Pro 1000. I honestly feel the Pro 1000 should be discontinued and no one should ever buy it. I mean really, the Pro 1500 is only $10 more right now and it destroys the Pro 1000.I would have given the Pro 1000 4 stars instead of just 3 if it had a Lithium Ion battery. They charge faster and last longer without charging.So yeah, I am not sure I would recommend the Pro 1000 if you can get the Pro 1500. The Pro 1500 is a much wiser purchase. I'm *extremely* happy with mine. It blows the Pro 1000 out of the water.

reviewTitle: I hate this toothbrush, but I'm going to keep it
reviewDescription: I had a Philips Sonicare for many years, that recently died. I bought this toothbrush primarily for the oscillating motion, since that's what dentists use (I literally had the thought as a child, "why don't our toothbrushes look like the dentist's?"). After using this Oral-B for a few days, I'm glad I bought it, but I also hate it.I hate that it *stutters* when it's time to switch tooth quadrants, vs the Sonicare that makes a gentle change in pitch. I hate that it doesn't stop after going through four quadrants, that it just stutters harder, and you have to turn it off manually (unlike the Sonicare). I hate that the noise is louder and harsher than the Sonicare. I hate that there is only one button, so you will always have to press it at least four times total during brushing in order to turn it off. I hate that I can't tell the difference between the brushing modes at all (the pitch seems to go *down* slightly when cycling, so is the first mode the strongest? I can't tell. Only thing I can tell is that the third setting seems to vary in velocity, which, why?). I REALLY hate that the instructions refer to it as type 3757, and in every distinct section of the instructions it never refers to that type number, but it does consistently refer to three *other* type numbers, leaving me totally in the dark on this toothbrush's functionality (particularly what the different brushing modes are, if they are different). I hate that it claims, on this very Amazon page, that there is a pressure sensor, but as hard as I press absolutely nothing changes (unlike the Sonicare); AND the instructions specifically say that the pressure sensor is only for type 3791. I also hate that the battery life is allegedly significantly worse than the Sonicare (supposedly one week only for the Oral-B, and I used to get a month on one charge brushing twice a day with the Sonicare).All that being said, it is more aggressive, and the oscillating motion does feel more thorough. In short, my teeth definitely feel cleaner after brushing with this vs the Sonicare. That plus the fact that brushheads are cheaper means I will stick with this even though I hate it. I'd advise others to consider a more expensive model if they address any of these myriad annoyances I've found.

I have used a different brand for years, but my dentist suggested I try an Oral B because it does as good a job and the brush heads (and in this case, also, the unit itself) are less expensive. He noted that the round brush head is easier to get into the molars all the way in the back. He especially recommended an Oral B because it is supposed to stop if you apply too much pressure.Well, it turns out I do like the small brush head a lot, and I don't  mind the noisiness of the Oral B. (My other brand emitted a tone--I think it was the B below middle C--that I enjoyed harmonizing with while I brushed, but never mind that!)  But I also have some disappointments:1) Maybe I got a bad unit, but I am astonished by how often it needs recharging--every few days, it seems. (I may call Oral-B tomorrow to ask about this.) Other reviews, I think, claimed that it held its charge for a long time.2) The brush does not stop pulsing if I apply too much pressure, as it is supposed to do. I have tried to make it stop, just to verify.3) The integrated button on the handle is not as responsive to the touch as I would like.  It requires more effort to shut it off than it should.4) I have no idea how to access the "3 EASY-TO-USE CLEANING MODES." Usually these things strike me as so much baloney, so that's not a make-or-break for me.(Also: I wish it came with a case.)It is not an expensive  model, and I don't need all the bells and whistles (bluetooth??!!). I am mostly irritated by the need to recharge it often.

I had the previous version of this brush for about 5 years before it began struggling to hold a charge. So I bought the updated version, and I'm honestly disappointed. Two things bother me in particular:1. The button, which used to be a slight bump, is now a slight divot. It is absurdly difficult to locate and press while operating the brush. I miss it almost every time, and when I manage to locate it with my finger, I have to press multiple times to get it to work. Can't imagine who thought it was a good idea to redesign a basic and functional feature in this frustrating way.2. The charging base quickly accumulates grime. I mean *very* quickly; after 3-4 uses, there is a dark oval of grime visible where the brush handle sits. This did not happen with the previous version of the brush. I can't even figure out where it's coming from, since toothpaste and water are not, you know, black. Part of me worries that there is something leaking out from the brush handle, though I can't see anything there. Either way, having to clean off the base every couple days is annoying.The good thing is that the brush still cleans my teeth as well as before. So I give it credit for that.

I’ve used Oral-b toothbrushes for quite a while and I have always liked them. After my last one died (it had lasted almost ten years) I was looking for something new but didn’t want to pay a lot. I settled on this one after looking at the pros and cons of the different models. It is much like the other models I have had with a couple of exceptions. First it doesn’t beep at each 30-second mark. Instead it pulses. Even after using it for six months I’m always thinking I’ve missed the pulse. The second issue is a bigger one.
